Speaker: mother
Dialogue: It hurts.

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: Don't push too fast! Breathe! The hard part is over. You can see the top of the head.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: It hurts. The pain.  It's tearing me.

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: Father, give her a hand.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Hey, this is too much.

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: You do your part.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Can you tell what it is?

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: Almost there.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: It's a junior.

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: Why don't you come in for a while?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I came all the way from Detroit by bus going to Oakland. The bus stopped in Los Angeles. I had to get off and take a rest. I'll catch the last bus leaving at midnight. I'm just too tired to go on.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Good evening. It must be all the different time zones I crossed that makes me feel this weary.

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: Don't pick up the cards if you are not in the game. Did he die?

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: Harry, what did you do, rob the graveyard?

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: I'm in church.

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: Suzie, you still have Joe's number?

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: I will have to look for it.

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: None of your business.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: That is a boy from home, Lulla's brother.

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: I was quoting from the Bible. If the shoe fits, wear it.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: How many people do you all feed?

Speaker: pat
Dialogue: I don't know if we could take one in with Rhonda and me at home alone at times.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Oh, I wasn't pointing my finger at you. Hey, you have to think of yourself. A lot of them have all kinds of diseases and will cut your throat while you sleep. There are too many bad people out there.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: I appreciate you lending me a hand. That lazy ass brother of mine was suppose to help me.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Well some folks are still waiting for their comeuppance. Don't take me wrong but you can't judge people by how you act. You're a caring person.

Speaker: pat
Dialogue: Why not? Harry says that's the only way to do good.

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Boy, that is the real South. That is real corn liquor.

Speaker: flim
Dialogue: What is in the bottle?

Speaker: herman
Dialogue: There is a fight in every bottle.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: You tappy heads better not tear down my house.

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: It is just a regular card.

Speaker: pat
Dialogue: He just leeches off your parents. He is a master at wearing out welcome.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Harry is the kind of guy you would love to take out in the woods and leave under a rock.

Speaker: pat
Dialogue: Where does her get the power to summon all his old raffish friends? They all smell of moth balls.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: How old is that boy?

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: Linda, how come you don't see that Sunny puts his shoes on right?

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Why don't you wait?

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: I could swear I heard my son call me.

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: Everybody who have been associated with Harry end up with pennies over their eyes.

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: Good afternoon to you.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: I ought to break your damn neck.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I came to pick up my things.

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: He dropped dead.

Speaker: herman
Dialogue: Hattie, you can be so mean.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: How long has he been dead?

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: Since this morning.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: What happened to your hand?

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: I cut it on an old rusty knife.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: What did you put on it?

Speaker: suzie
Dialogue: It's healing now.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: I hope you will take care of your mother better than that when I'm gone.

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: How come you're not wearing my shoes?

Speaker: babe brother
Dialogue: They're too big.

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: I wonder how they going to bury this man.

Speaker: herman
Dialogue: Hattie, your true colors are unbearable. You got some mean ways. Don't worry about the boy getting a burial. He still has some friends left on this earth.
